These projects encourage students to address critical issues, ranging from local community challenges to global concerns, while fostering a sense of responsibility and teamwork.

question_text:
Complete the sentence below using information from the passage.
The 'Student Workshop Hub' event at Bright Future Secondary School was ________
answer: a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood
an event that engaged students, parents, and teachers in addressing school and neighborhood issues through creative solutions

related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever "Student Workshop Hub," a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

question_text: What was the purpose behind organizing the 'Student Workshop Hub' at Bright Future Secondary School? Choose all the correct answers.

options.A: To showcase students' creative solutions to school and neighborhood problems
options.B: To transform the school campus into a creative hotspot for community-minded projects
options.C: To encourage students to study traditional academic subjects
options.D: To help students take pride in contributing to something bigger than themselves
options.E: To celebrate the school's tenth anniversary

related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever "Student Workshop Hub," a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

The event was organized by Emma and Paul Gibson, long-time educators who had envisioned turning the campus into a creative hotspot for community-minded projects. When they opened Bright Future Secondary School ten years ago, their dream was to create a space where students could not only study but also explore skills spanning technology, design, and even small-scale manufacturing. Their vision came to life with this event.

The idea for the Student Workshop Hub came to Emma when she noticed how much her own children enjoyed school activities that required them to solve real-world problems. From recycling initiatives to building birdhouses for local parks, students seemed to take pride in being part of something bigger than themselves. Emma became determined to bring a similar experience to Bright Future Secondary School.

question_text: Which of the following is closest in meaning to ‘pride’ in paragraph 6?

related_paragraphs.text: The idea for the Student Workshop Hub came to Emma when she noticed how much her own children enjoyed school activities that required them to solve real-world problems. From recycling initiatives to building birdhouses for local parks, students seemed to take pride in being part of something bigger than themselves. Emma became determined to bring a similar experience to Bright Future Secondary School.

question_text: Use ONE word to complete each blank.
text_for_fill: The Student Workshop Hub encourages students to solve ___ ___ problems. Paul emphasized that such activities show children how ___ their actions are to the wider environment, and the campaign gained ___ support with contributions from parents, administrators, and teachers who incorporated the workshops into their ___ .

related_paragraphs.text: The idea for the Student Workshop Hub came to Emma when she noticed how much her own children enjoyed school activities that required them to solve real-world problems. From recycling initiatives to building birdhouses for local parks, students seemed to take pride in being part of something bigger than themselves. Emma became determined to bring a similar experience to Bright Future Secondary School.

Paul also saw a unique opportunity to combine educational goals with environmental awareness: 'Projects like these teach students how interconnected the world is. Whether they're improving green spaces in our city or creating art installations with recycled materials, kids start to see how their actions ripple outward.'

The campaign prompted widespread enthusiasm. Parents offered to contribute materials, school administrators provided funding, and teachers incorporated elements of the workshop into their lessons. Among the highlights of the week were workshops where students learned woodworking, coding, and sustainable gardening techniques.

question_text: What does Nia believe projects like hers teach, as described in paragraph 11?

related_paragraphs.text: Beyond environmental work, twelve-year-old Nia worked on a social project aimed at helping underprivileged children access educational supplies. 'We collected unused items like pencils, notebooks, and rulers and distributed them to local families in need,' Nia explained. She believes projects like hers teach empathy and resourcefulness: 'A small gesture can make a big difference.'

question_text: What does 'gesture' in paragraph 11 refer to?
answer: helping underprivileged children access educational items

related_paragraphs.text: Beyond environmental work, twelve-year-old Nia worked on a social project aimed at helping underprivileged children access educational supplies. 'We collected unused items like pencils, notebooks, and rulers and distributed them to local families in need,' Nia explained. She believes projects like hers teach empathy and resourcefulness: 'A small gesture can make a big difference.'

question_text: Based on the information in the text, match each statement to the person or group it describes. One statement is NOT used. Write NG (not given) if the statement is not mentioned in the text.

statements.text: They were inspired by the students’ dedication and helped organize their work.
They supported the students in budgeting and marketing their ideas.
They aim to focus on mental health awareness projects in the next year.
They believe the skills students gain here will help them in a rapidly changing world.
They organized a global education initiative connecting students from different countries.

related_paragraphs.text: Meanwhile, Phyllis Watson, a retired local librarian who volunteered during the hub, was inspired by how far-reaching the students' efforts had been. 'The dedication these kids show is nothing short of incredible. Seeing them put their thoughts into tangible projects is very uplifting,' said Phyllis as she helped organize folders showcasing students' work.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

The Student Workshop Hub, according to Emma, is just the first of many initiatives planned for Bright Future Secondary School. 'This is the beginning. Next year, we aim to tackle projects focused on mental health awareness, local history preservation, and even global initiatives connecting students from different countries,' she said.

Paul shared similar optimism: 'The skills our students are gaining through these projects — teamwork, innovation, and resilience — will stick with them for life. We're giving them the toolkit to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing world.'

question_text: Read paragraph 16. Find an expression that means the same as 'get ready to succeed'.

related_paragraphs.text: Paul shared similar optimism: "The skills our students are gaining through these projects — teamwork, innovation, and resilience — will stick with them for life. We're giving them the toolkit to adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing world."

question_text: Why is the Student Workshop Hub considered a success by the contributors?

answer: it highlighted cultural diversity and societal issues
students put their ideas into (tangible) projects
parents' involvement (was a key factor in its success)
it set the stage for future initiatives

related_paragraphs.text: Other standout moments included performances conducted by the Arts and Drama Club highlighting cultural diversity, traditional folklore, and modern interpretations of societal changes. "Art has the ability to foster understanding," said Alan, a sixteen-year-old aspiring theater director. His group performed a play that explored shifting family dynamics in modern society, which resonated with many attendees.

Meanwhile, Phyllis Watson, a retired local librarian who volunteered during the hub, was inspired by how far-reaching the students' efforts had been. "The dedication these kids show is nothing short of incredible. Seeing them put their thoughts into tangible projects is very uplifting," said Phyllis as she helped organize folders showcasing students' work.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

The Student Workshop Hub, according to Emma, is just the first of many initiatives planned for Bright Future Secondary School. "This is the beginning. Next year, we aim to tackle projects focused on mental health awareness, local history preservation, and even global initiatives connecting students from different countries," she said.

answer: they will focus on mental health awareness, local history preservation, and global connections
the projects will address topics like mental health awareness and preserving local history
future plans include connecting students from different countries through global initiatives

question_text: Decide whether the following statements are True, False, or Not Given based on paragraphs 12–18.

statements.text: Alan's group performed a play about cultural diversity.
Phyllis believes that the students are incredibly dedicated.
Emma and Paul think parents' involvement was crucial for the success of the hub.
Students from Bright Future Secondary School are planning to connect with schools in neighboring cities next year.
The open house event attracted more than 700 attendees.

related_paragraphs.text: Other standout moments included performances conducted by the Arts and Drama Club highlighting cultural diversity, traditional folklore, and modern interpretations of societal changes. "Art has the ability to foster understanding," said Alan, a sixteen-year-old aspiring theater director. His group performed a play that explored shifting family dynamics in modern society, which resonated with many attendees.

Meanwhile, Phyllis Watson, a retired local librarian who volunteered during the hub, was inspired by how far-reaching the students' efforts had been. "The dedication these kids show is nothing short of incredible. Seeing them put their thoughts into tangible projects is very uplifting," said Phyllis as she helped organize folders showcasing students' work.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

At the end of the week, students proudly presented their completed projects during an open house event attended by nearly 700 community members. Their ingenuity was celebrated, and many visitors left inspired by the potential for schools to cultivate meaningful change. Bright Future Secondary School is already planning the next session of the hub, which promises more opportunities for students to innovate and grow.

question_text: Put the events mentioned below in the correct order. Write (1-5) in the boxes provided.

statements.text: Lara and her classmates created an outdoor terrace project.
The Student Workshop Hub event was hosted at Bright Future Secondary School.
Ethan developed a system to track classroom energy usage.
Nia started a social project to help underprivileged children access educational supplies.
Students presented their completed projects to the community during an open house event.

related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever 'Student Workshop Hub,' a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

Fifteen-year-old Lara and her classmates formed a group called 'Eco School Advocates' and worked tirelessly on an outdoor terrace project. 'We wanted to create a shared space in our school where people could relax and connect with nature,' Lara explained. Her group planted native grass species, installed seating made from re-purposed wood, and produced a mural illustrating how ecosystems thrive when people work harmoniously with nature.

Thirteen-year-old Ethan was equally dedicated, putting his energy into developing an automated system for tracking classroom energy usage. 'I realized that lights were often left on when no one was around,' Ethan said. 'So I built code that monitors energy consumption and sends alerts when electricity is being wasted.' The technology drew interest from both teachers and school administrators.

Beyond environmental work, twelve-year-old Nia worked on a social project aimed at helping underprivileged children access educational supplies. 'We collected unused items like pencils, notebooks, and rulers and distributed them to local families in need,' Nia explained. She believes projects like hers teach empathy and resourcefulness: 'A small gesture can make a big difference.'

At the end of the week, students proudly presented their completed projects during an open house event attended by nearly 700 community members. Their ingenuity was celebrated, and many visitors left inspired by the potential for schools to cultivate meaningful change. Bright Future Secondary School is already planning the next session of the hub, which promises more opportunities for students to innovate and grow.

statements.text: Empowering environmental change
Students team up for empathy
Creativity transforms education

"We wanted to create a shared space in our school where people could relax and connect with nature," Lara explained. Her group planted native grass species, installed seating made from re-purposed wood, and produced a mural illustrating how ecosystems thrive when people work harmoniously with nature.

Beyond environmental work, twelve-year-old Nia worked on a social project aimed at helping underprivileged children access educational supplies. "We collected unused items like pencils, notebooks, and rulers and distributed them to local families in need," Nia explained. She believes projects like hers teach empathy and resourcefulness: "A small gesture can make a big difference."

Education is evolving, and schools around the world are embracing innovative approaches to learning. From community outreach to hands-on creative projects, students are being challenged to think critically and develop real-world skills. At the heart of this transformation are initiatives designed to make learning interactive, engaging, and impactful.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

"We wanted to create a shared space in our school where people could relax and connect with nature," Lara explained. Her group planted native grass species, installed seating made from re-purposed wood, and produced a mural illustrating how ecosystems thrive when people work harmoniously with nature.

question_text: Which of the following is the best alternative title for this text?

related_paragraphs.title: Shaping the Future, One Lesson at a Time

related_paragraphs.subtitle: Innovative School Projects Inspire Students to Learn and Grow

related_paragraphs.text: Education is evolving, and schools around the world are embracing innovative approaches to learning. From community outreach to hands-on creative projects, students are being challenged to think critically and develop real-world skills. At the heart of this transformation are initiatives designed to make learning interactive, engaging, and impactful.

Through these kinds of programs, schools worldwide are empowering students to turn ideas into action and showing them how to make a meaningful impact, both inside and outside the classroom. As education continues to evolve, initiatives like the Student Workshop Hub will undoubtedly inspire generations of learners to shape a brighter, more connected future.

question_text: Complete the summary of the text by writing ONE word to fill in each blank. You should make sure your answers are grammatically correct, paying attention to tenses, plurals, etc.
text_for_fill: The Student Workshop Hub was first held at Bright Future Secondary School, a facility located in ___, Canada. Organized by Emma and Paul Gibson, the event aimed to transform the school into a ___ of innovation while cultivating teamwork and accountability among students. During the workshop, students applied their skills to create practical solutions to real-world ___ affecting their school and local ___ . Among the many student projects, Lara and her classmates developed an outdoor terrace with seating created from ___ wood. Ethan built an automated system to track classroom energy ___ and provided alerts to address instances of ___ electricity usage. The Arts and Drama Club put on performances exploring cultural ___ , such as folklore, family dynamics, and societal change. Parents contributed significantly to the hub's success by providing ___ support and mentoring students in areas like logistics and budgeting. The hub was deemed a ___ by all participants and is set to grow even further with upcoming initiatives addressing mental health and global ___ .

related_paragraphs.text: Last month, a bustling workshop atmosphere brought together students, parents, and teachers at Bright Future Secondary School. Located in Ontario, Canada, the school hosted its first-ever "Student Workshop Hub," a week-long event where students showcased creative solutions to problems affecting their school and neighborhood.

The event was organized by Emma and Paul Gibson, long-time educators who had envisioned turning the campus into a creative hotspot for community-minded projects. When they opened Bright Future Secondary School ten years ago, their dream was to create a space where students could not only study but also explore skills spanning technology, design, and even small-scale manufacturing. Their vision came to life with this event.

Fifteen-year-old Lara and her classmates formed a group called "Eco School Advocates" and worked tirelessly on an outdoor terrace project. "We wanted to create a shared space in our school where people could relax and connect with nature," Lara explained. Her group planted native grass species, installed seating made from re-purposed wood, and produced a mural illustrating how ecosystems thrive when people work harmoniously with nature.

Thirteen-year-old Ethan was equally dedicated, putting his energy into developing an automated system for tracking classroom energy usage. "I realized that lights were often left on when no one was around," Ethan said. "So I built code that monitors energy consumption and sends alerts when electricity is being wasted." The technology drew interest from both teachers and school administrators.

Other standout moments included performances conducted by the Arts and Drama Club highlighting cultural diversity, traditional folklore, and modern interpretations of societal changes. "Art has the ability to foster understanding," said Alan, a sixteen-year-old aspiring theater director. His group performed a play that explored shifting family dynamics in modern society, which resonated with many attendees.

As Emma and Paul reflected on the hub's success, they pointed to the parents' involvement as a key factor in bringing their vision to life. Many parents not only supported the event financially but also mentored students in areas like budgeting, marketing their ideas, and logistics.

The Student Workshop Hub, according to Emma, is just the first of many initiatives planned for Bright Future Secondary School. "This is the beginning. Next year, we aim to tackle projects focused on mental health awareness, local history preservation, and even global initiatives connecting students from different countries," she said.
